comment.author: 75671375@N05
comment._content: Surprisingly, the "Gun Powder Office" survived the Rising without being shelled or blown up by its own contents getting too hot.  ;-)  By 1916 the "Kelly's Fishing Tackle Manufactory" on the lower signage had become "M. Kelly & Sons Fishing Tackle", and was moved up to top billing on the wall, while the Gun Powder Office lettering got smaller and lower-down on the building.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: What a super shot!  There is so much going on here you could stare at it for ever and find new things all the time.  The jewellers on the corner of Eden Quay "Hopkins and Hopkins late of Law and Sons were there right up to the mid '70's at least.  See all the dung on the street (great for roses) and the man pushing the handcart with the milk churn?  Brilliant!

comment.author: 22575440@N07
comment._content: just exactly what bldg is the photo being taken from? Is it the one on the corner at D'olier st, the John Purcell bldg?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Hi tammybeck it would appear to be the one that was on the corner dividing D'olier Street from Westmoreland Stree and  the quays.  It was replaced by that hideous Liffey House (?) building that the Driving Licence section were based in for many years.

comment.author: 9827553@N07
comment._content:
That statue on the other end of O'Connell Street was Nelson's Pillar. I think it was destroyed by IRA in the 1960s. 

I love old pictures like this.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Just looking at the view, the statue in the foreground is no longer in that position. I think that it is now in or near Trinity College nearby. It appears to be surrounded by those self same perforated bollards that caused so much amusement a few weeks ago in that photograph near the Parnell monument at the other end of O'Connell Street. www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/6509876797/in/photostream/ Incidentally I see no signs of that said Parnell monument which must not have been erected at the time as he was still alive (RIP 1891) and still a cause for division and dissension. The pillar was destroyed in 1966 by an IRA bomb and has been replaced by the dreadful "Spire". Bring back Horatio I say!!!

comment.author: 34574252@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] The Parnell Monument's foundation stone was laid on 8th Oct 1899 and the monument was unveiled on 1st Oct 1911. The bronze statue was the work of Irish born sculptor Augustus Saint-Gaudens.

comment.author: 75671375@N05
comment._content:
Regarding my earlier comment, the Gunpowder Office wasn't left nearly as unscathed in the Rising as it might appear to us in photos. I was recently rereading James Stephens' An Insurrection in Dublin, and came across this passage pertinent to the Gunpowder Office -- Stephens identifies the building as Kelly's Fishing Tackle without mentioning the Gunpowder Office, but it's the same building:
"I was looking on O'Connell Bridge and Sackville Street, and the house facing me was Kelly's—a red-brick fishing tackle shop, one half of which was on the Quay and the other half in Sackville Street. This house was being bombarded. "I counted the report of six different machine guns which played on it. Rifles innumerable and from every sort of place were potting its windows, and at intervals of about half a minute the shells from a heavy gun lobbed in through its windows or thumped mightily against its walls. "For three hours that bombardment continued, and the walls stood in a cloud of red dust and smoke. Rifle and machine gun bullets pattered over every inch of it, and, unfailingly the heavy gun pounded its shells through the windows. "One's heart melted at the idea that human beings were crouching inside that volcano of death, and I said to myself, "Not even a fly can be alive in that house." "No head showed at any window, no rifle cracked from window or roof in reply. The house was dumb, lifeless, and I thought every one of those men are dead. "It was then, and quite suddenly, that the possibilities of street fighting flashed on me, and I knew there was no person in the house, and said to myself, "They have smashed through the walls with a hatchet and are sitting in the next house, or they have long ago climbed out by the skylight and are on a roof half a block away." Then the thought came to me—they have and hold the entire of Sackville Street down to the Post Office. Later on this proved to be the case, and I knew at this moment that Sackville Street was doomed. "I continued to watch the bombardment, but no longer with the anguish which had before torn me. . . ."
Stephens later writes:
"About five o'clock the guns eased off of Kelly's. "To inexperienced eyes they did not seem to have done very much damage, but afterwards one found that although the walls were standing and apparently solid there was no inside to the house. From roof to basement the building was bare as a dog kennel. There were no floors inside, there was nothing there but blank space; and on the ground within was the tumble and rubbish that had been roof and floors and furniture. Everything inside was smashed and pulverised into scrap and dust, and the only objects that had consistency and their ancient shape were the bricks that fell when the shells struck them."

comment.author: 75671375@N05

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Chancellor and Sons. I see they were advertising a range of watches (Freeman's, Jan 30th 1878) costing between £2 and £10. £2- Silver case, horizontal escapement, well finished, strong and serviceable, specially adapted for boys at school £10 - Gold case, plain engine-turned or engraved, our own make, patent lever escapement, capped, jewelled, and fitted with all recent improvements; engaged for ten years. =============================================================== By 1888 (Freeman's, June 1) they had branched out:
ART PHOTOGRAPHY CHANCELLOR & SONS PHOTOGRAPHERS to H.R.H. THE PRINCE OF WALES PORTRAITS IN PLATINOTYPE A SPECIALITY A MOVABLE BOUDOIR conveys SITTERS to the Galleries, thus obviating the trouble of ascending the stairs. Appointments can be made by letter or at THE STUDIO 55 LOWER SACKVILLE STREET, DUBLIN
I used to work in a building which had a movable boudoir, but we called it the 'lift'. The OED has citations for 'lift' in the sense of "An apparatus for raising or lowering persons or things from one floor or level to another" from 1851, so 'movable boudoir' sounds like a bit of creative excess by an advertising copywriter. Nevertheless, it's the phrase I am going to use from now on. And I can't help thinking that Library Towers must have its fair share of movable boudoirs. ==================================================================== And in 1899 they could improve your eyesight:
Special periscopic axis-cut pebbles The most perfect lenses ever manufactured, mounted in patent non-rusting frames, one guinea ----- TO SUIT ALL SIGHTS ----- New test types and Treatise of the Eyesight. Post free.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] John, I'm in stitches reading this. We do indeed have an "elegant sufficiency" of movable boudoirs at Library Towers, and I too shall use this phrase from now on. Should I become stuck between floors, I'll delight in ringing the alarm and telling whoever answers that "one is stuck in the movable boudoir at the National Library of Ireland"...  :)

P.S.  I bet Arthur Henri (aka A.H. Poole) must have been raging that he didn't have one of those conveyances in his studios in Waterford.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Tall electric light lamp-posts were placed along O'Connell Street and the bridge in 1892, so this photo must be before then. They are visible in the 1896 photo linked above. Info from - www.archiseek.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=49&t=3968 [also loving "movable boudoirs"]
